awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Deep Roots: Wide-Spread Implementation of Community-Driven Evidence-Based Pedagogy
awd_abstract_narration:
This multi-university institutional transformation project, led by the University of Kansas, will both implement and study a model to improve STEM education within seven universities. The ultimate goal is to propagate widespread adoption of evidence-based instructional methods in order to improve undergraduate STEM learning and educational outcomes for both STEM and non-STEM students. Five American institutions funded by this grant, as well as two unfunded Canadian institutions, will test local adaptations of the model on their own campuses. The model is derived from research on institutional change and quality improvement, and builds on an extensive successful initiative (known as the Science Education Initiative, SEI) at two of the partner institutions the University of Colorado at Boulder and the University of British Columbia. The core approach is to support "embedded expertise" in STEM departments to catalyze course transformation and build intellectual communities within and across institutions, in order to share in the development of course reform.  The other participating institutions are the University of Texas at San Antonio, Indiana University, the University of California, Davis, and Queens University in Canada.  

The model of transformation involves embedding STEM education experts (specially prepared postdoctoral scholars or faculty leaders) in departments. These experts will collaborate with department faculty to guide and support the implementation of research-based educational practices in STEM courses. This extension of the SEI model supports change with a smaller infusion of resources by developing communities of scholars around course transformation across departments and institutions. These communities broaden the impact of the embedded experts by expanding support and opportunities for reflective practice for faculty, contributing to the development of a shared vision, and encouraging a critical mass of faculty engagement within departments needed to produce meaningful changes in the teaching environment. Seven research universities that have been actively collaborating through the Bay View Alliance will each implement and evaluate variations of this model on their own campuses. The network serves two functions: 1) to build a community for intellectual exchange and collaboration on evidence-based teaching as a key component of the intervention itself, and 2) to permit a test of whether the intervention model can be localized to different institutional contexts to yield widespread STEM reform.  A combination of quantitative and case study evaluation methods are planned to identify the various dimensions and conditions that signal initial readiness, successful approaches, and sustainable outcomes in participating institutions.

inst.inst_name: University of Texas at San Antonio
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT SAN ANTONIO

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas at San Antonio

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research grant established TRESTLE, a team that has created cross-institutional ownership of an embedded expert model for course redesign, data collection, and impact analysis.  TRESTLE created a robust, searchable, complete database that includes data from multiple instruments and collection sources, which has enabled rich analyses of the results within individual campuses and across the network.  A TRESTLE website shares results of individual course transformations for broad dissemination of the work. The effectiveness of the collaboration was evaluated externally, which identified challenges and enabled the TRESTLE group to create common themes for successful implementation in a variety of academic settings. Based on the experiences of the TRESTLE researchers, a Course Transformation rubric was developed to provide a framework for characterizing activities with highest impact. Finally, guiding TRESTLE Principles were identified that are adaptable to complex environments such as those found in higher education, which include concepts around defining course redesign, evidence-based approaches, human capital requirements, expertise needed, focus on departmental empowerment, building a community for fostering change, and providing visibility to the changes.

 

The most impactful outcomes at UTSA can be summarized within four primary areas: 1) increasing learning within engineering disciplines, 2) building interdisciplinary research teams of change agents, 3) providing a methodology for re-designing interdisciplinary courses within a new College of Engineering and Integrated Design, and 4) establishing an Engineering Education program within the new College. 

 

  1. Course evaluations and observations noted an increase in active learning approaches, increased passing rates and average student grades, and increased persistence toward earning a degree.
  2. Ten engineering faculty members worked closely with faculty from the College of Education and Human Development to re-design engineering courses.  These partnerships have lasted beyond the TRESTLE work and have led to new funded research projects.
  3. The new College used principles developed through TRESTLE to re-design courses with integrated and project-oriented curricula to increase learning and prepare graduates for the modern workforce.  Incentives are offered for faculty to pair across areas of expertise and create new curricula and educational outcomes. 
  4. Three new Engineering Faculty were hired, jointly appointed between the College of Engineering and Integrated Design and the College of Education and Human Development, to begin a new Masters in Engineering Education focused on improving student learning in higher education engineering programs, with specialty serving Hispanic and first-generation college student populations such as those in the majority at UTSA.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2022
Modified by: Joann P Browning
por.por_txt_cntn:
This collaborative research grant established TRESTLE, a team that has created cross-institutional ownership of an embedded expert model for course redesign, data collection, and impact analysis.  TRESTLE created a robust, searchable, complete database that includes data from multiple instruments and collection sources, which has enabled rich analyses of the results within individual campuses and across the network.  A TRESTLE website shares results of individual course transformations for broad dissemination of the work. The effectiveness of the collaboration was evaluated externally, which identified challenges and enabled the TRESTLE group to create common themes for successful implementation in a variety of academic settings. Based on the experiences of the TRESTLE researchers, a Course Transformation rubric was developed to provide a framework for characterizing activities with highest impact. Finally, guiding TRESTLE Principles were identified that are adaptable to complex environments such as those found in higher education, which include concepts around defining course redesign, evidence-based approaches, human capital requirements, expertise needed, focus on departmental empowerment, building a community for fostering change, and providing visibility to the changes.

 

The most impactful outcomes at UTSA can be summarized within four primary areas: 1) increasing learning within engineering disciplines, 2) building interdisciplinary research teams of change agents, 3) providing a methodology for re-designing interdisciplinary courses within a new College of Engineering and Integrated Design, and 4) establishing an Engineering Education program within the new College. 

 

Course evaluations and observations noted an increase in active learning approaches, increased passing rates and average student grades, and increased persistence toward earning a degree.
Ten engineering faculty members worked closely with faculty from the College of Education and Human Development to re-design engineering courses.  These partnerships have lasted beyond the TRESTLE work and have led to new funded research projects.
The new College used principles developed through TRESTLE to re-design courses with integrated and project-oriented curricula to increase learning and prepare graduates for the modern workforce.  Incentives are offered for faculty to pair across areas of expertise and create new curricula and educational outcomes.  
Three new Engineering Faculty were hired, jointly appointed between the College of Engineering and Integrated Design and the College of Education and Human Development, to begin a new Masters in Engineering Education focused on improving student learning in higher education engineering programs, with specialty serving Hispanic and first-generation college student populations such as those in the majority at UTSA.
